div.p: Greetings. After I published my Fifth Decade and freed myself from the pressure of the press, I wrote to you, esteemed lord and brother in the Lord, and also sent a copy of my Decade. Later, I wrote again in the month of March and once more in April, and in May I entrusted letters to a certain Flemish man named Johann, who called himself Utenhove, and at the same time, writing to our friend Gast, I instructed him to have shared letters with you. But if you have written even once since that time, I am unaware. I know that you were gravely ill; but even then I wrote consolatory letters. Meanwhile, since you have recovered, I am quite sure that you have not lacked the leisure to write.

Therefore, I write to you again, greet you, and wish to know the state of your affairs. We are well here, except that there is a great abundance of poor people and a scarcity of all things. The Lord punishes our unrestrained indulgence in the world. Many predict that a very serious war will arise; if a plague accompanies it, we will have a scourge prepared worthy of three scorpions, whose lashes will be inflicted most severely. May the Lord preserve His church in these tribulations. Farewell. Most swiftly.
To the most excellent man, Lord Oswald Myconius, his most esteemed lord and brother.
